Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and Management of Change (MOC)
Salt Creek has established and implemented a Management of Change procedure to manage changes to process chemicals, procedures, technology, and equipment. Employees (including contractors) involved in operating and maintaining the process are informed of, and trained in, the process change prior to startup of the affected process section.
 
A PSSR is completed for any new facility modification or other change as described in the company Management of Change procedure. The purpose of the PSSR is to verify safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as assurance

that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.  Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 10.

Mechanical Integrity
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant has a formal Mechanical Integrity program to ensure that equipment used to process, store or handle highly hazardous chemicals or flammables is maintained in accordance with design or manufacturer's recommendations.
 
Inspections and tests performed on process equipment are consistent with applicable manufacturers' recommendations, good engineering practices, industry standards and actual experience.

Deficiencies which are outside acceptable limits are corrected before further use (or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to verify safe operation). The facility ensures fabricated equipment is suitable for the process application and is installed properly prior to startup.  Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 10. 

Hot Work
Salt Creek has safe work practices as mandated by OSHA and the EPA to help provide employee, public and process safety.  Refer to the Hot Work Policy in the Company HES Manual.

Incident Investigation
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations, and provides an overview to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions are tracked to closure, and investigation reports are retained for at least five years. Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 12.  

Compliance Audits
A compliance audit addressing all OSHA PSM and EPA RMP requirements is conducted at least every three year

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
Salt Creek Midstream, LLC (Salt Creek) is committed to both worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, training, quality assurance, and the consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent releases of regulated substances. 
DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Salt Creek owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant, in Reeves County, Texas. The plant is designed to process 200 MMSCFD of natural gas and utilizes the Cryogenic Process to recover natural gas liquids.  Regulated Flammable Substances recovered by or involved in the process include:

1.	Flammable NGL (Y-Grade) composed of:
a.	Methane
b.	Ethane
c.	Propane
d.	Butane
e.	Isobutane
f.	Pentane

2.	Propane, used as a refrigerant

Residue gas removed from the process is shipped out via a residue gas pipeline.
GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Employee Participation
Salt Creek encourages employees to participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management (PSM) and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the facility and addresses each accident prevention program element. Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 1.


Process Safety Information
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of the process. These docum

ents address chemical properties and associated hazards, (b) limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and (c) equipment design basis/configuration information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.

For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g. temperature, level, and composition). The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g. automated shutdown systems).

The facility also maintains documentation that provides information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as evaluating proposed changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised. Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 2.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
Salt Creek has implemented a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the PSM/RMP covered process. Process Hazard Analysis Studies (PHAs) are conducted using the HAZOP methodology, with a team of Salt Creek employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates potential hazards and makes recommendations to mitigate the risk.  The final recommendations are tracked to closure, and resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility periodi

cally updates and revalidates PHAs. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are also documented and retained.  Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 3.

Operating Procedures
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for the training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed to maintain correctness and annually certified as current and accurate.  These procedures are readily available in the facility for operators and other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task.  Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 4.

Training
Salt Creek has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator learns process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years, or more frequently if requested. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.  Refer to Salt Creek Midstream PSM/RMP Manual- Section 5.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Hazards at the Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.

Specialized Safety Features
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant has safety features to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release (mitigation). The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:
-Release Detection
-Release Containment/Control
-Process relief valves that discharge to a vent stack or flare
-Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
-Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
-Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases
-Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup pumps)
-Fire extinguishers
-Trained personnel
-Personal protective equipment

Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program summarized above is applied to all RMP covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accidents that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.
FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant has had no RMP-regulated substance releases during the past five years.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Salt Creek Midstream Pecos Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency respon

se plan, which is in place to help protect employee and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including:

1.	Proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, 
2.	Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,
3.	Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate. Salt Creek has 24/7 communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, Salt Creek conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for plant personnel.
